prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for getting correcting people for shortening my name?
My name is Joanna. I have many nick names but “joanne” is not one of them. I sign all my emails at work  with Jo or Joanna. When I introduce myself I always let people know they can call me Joanna, Jo, Jojo, hell I’ll even answer to Josephine! Just don’t drop that A if you’re going with my full name. 

The one thing I ask is not to be called Joanne. Inevitably people will go right to it. 

So, AITA for continually correcting people that I prefer all the other naming versions I offer - just don’t call me Joanne?? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so the user is asking whether the author of the "Am I the Asshole" post is in the wrong for correcting people who shorten their name to "Joanne" when their name is Joanna. Let me break this down.

First, the author's name is Joanna, but people keep calling her Joanne, which she doesn't like. She mentions her nicknames are Jo, Joanna, Jojo, or even Josephine, but specifically tells people not to drop the 'A' in her full name. Despite this, people still use Joanne. She's asking if she's wrong for correcting them.

The key points here are about personal boundaries and respect for names. People have the right to correct others if they're being misnamed. The author is clear about her preferences and is consistent in stating them. She's not being aggressive, just correcting when necessary. It's her name, so she has the right to choose how she's addressed. The people misnaming her are the ones not respecting her preference, not her for correcting them. So the answer would be B, the author is not in the wrong.
